THE PROPOSAL

1.
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  Report  and  Recommendation  on  a
proposed loan to the Independent State of Samoa for the Education Sector Project.  The

II.

INTRODUCTION

2.
Samoa  is  an  archipelago  of  seven  islands  located  in  the  South  Pacific,
approximately 2,400 kilometers (km) north-east of New Zealand.  The population of the
country  is  estimated  at  170,000,  a  figure  projected  from  the  last  census  (1991).    The
average population density is 56 persons per square km (km2), although a large majority
of the people live in the coastal areas of the two main islands of Upolu (72 percent of the
population)  and  Savai’i  (27  percent).    About  35,000  people  (over  20  percent  of  the
population) live in Apia, the capital, in Upolu. The country is geographically compact and
has  a  good  road  and  shipping  network.    Transport  between  and  within  islands  is
relatively easy, and access to Government services is generally good.

Large  external  emigration  flows,  averaging  over  2  percent  of  the  population
3.
(around 3,500 persons) annually, have kept the overall population growth relatively low
in recent years. The majority of the emigrants are men aged 20-30 seeking employment
abroad.    It  is  estimated  that  up  to  70  percent  of  Samoans  who  have  completed  post-
secondary  education  will  emigrate.  While  this  massive  emigration  of  well-educated
Samoans  is  of  concern  to  the  Government,  it  is  also  recognized  that  remittance
contributions  from  Samoans  residing  abroad  continue  to  have  a  significant  positive
impact on the national economy and the balance of payments. Remittances are the most
important and stable source of income in the economy and is the single most important
source of monetary income at the village level. They constitute a very important factor in
offsetting  the  vulnerability  to  climatic  conditions,  crop  diseases,  and  volatile  world
markets.

Samoa has a total land area of 2,820 km2, with an exclusive economic zone of
4.
98,000 km2, the smallest in the Pacific.  About 43 percent of the land area is classified as
arable and about 75 percent of the population still use land and coastal resources as a
main  or  supplementary  source  of  income.  However,  Samoa  is  ecologically  fragile  and
vulnerable  to  environmental  degradation  and  cyclones.  An  estimated  30  percent  of
agricultural production takes place in areas with severe soil limitation and the clearing of
steeper slopes increases the vulnerability to erosion.

5.
Samoa has made reasonable economic progress in the past two decades. In the
1980s  a  modest  economic  growth  averaging  about  1.7  percent  per  annum  was
achieved. In the early 1990s real incomes weakened, reflecting the devastation caused
by  two  major  cyclones  in  1990  and  1991,  and  the  adverse  impact  of  taro  leaf  blight
disease in 1993-1994. However, the economy subsequently recovered, with high growth
rates in 1996-1997.  In 1999, the growth rate of the economy accelerated to 5.3 percent,
from 3.4 percent in 1998, reflecting strong growth in commerce, hotels, and restaurants;
transportation  and  communication;  construction;  and  fisheries.  A  9  percent  increase  in
tourist arrivals stimulated the commerce and transport sectors.

6.

averaging 18.7 percent. The majority of the population still relies on subsistence farming
and  fishing  as  well  as  cash  crops,  such  as  copra,  taro,  cocoa,  and  bananas.    The
contribution of the public sector to GDP also remained relatively stable during the period
and averaged 9.8 percent. While the contribution of industry to GDP steadily decreased
from 30.7 percent in 1994 to about 23.7 percent in 1998, the contribution of the services
sector expanded further from 41.3 percent in 1994 to 47.4 percent in 1998 (Appendix 1).

Quality of Life

III.

BACKGROUND

The vision expressed in the Government’s Partnership for a Prosperous Society:
8.
A Statement of Economic Strategy 2000-2001 (SES) aims at improving the quality of life
for  all  Samoans.  Poverty  is  not  explicitly  mentioned  in  the  SES,  and  no  actions  in  the
strategy  are  aimed  directly  at  reducing  poverty.  Poverty,  in  the  absolute  sense,  is  not
seen  as  a  critical  issue  in  the  Samoan  context.  Samoa  is  in  the  category  of  countries
with  medium-level  human  development.  Using  the  human  development  index  (HDI),
which  encompasses  the  three  dimensions  of  longevity,  knowledge,  and  income,
Samoa’s  score  of  0.59  ranks  it  seventh  among  15  Pacific  Island  countries  and  117th
among developing countries. Samoa exhibits a low level of poverty as measured by the
human poverty index (HPI), which measures access to basic services. With a HPI of 8.6,
Samoa again ranks seventh among 15 Pacific Island countries.1  The community-based
sociocultural system generally ensures that no one is completely destitute.

To define the poverty situation in Samoa, the concept of relative poverty may be
9.
more  appropriate  than  that  of  absolute  poverty,  which  would  imply  complete  material
deprivation.  In  Samoa  poverty  is  rarely  as  visible  and  as  extreme  as  it  is  in  the  poorer
countries  of  Asia.  But  relative  poverty  exists,  as  there  are  people  who  are  truly
disadvantaged and deprived compared with others in the community, or nation.

10.
Considering  the  mix  of  traditional  subsistence  activities,  modest  cash  income
activities,  and  private  remittances  encountered  in  the  traditional  Samoan  society,  it  is
difficult to make a rigorous assessment of the existing poverty situation.  The household
income  and  expenditure  data  for  1972  and  1997,  however,  clearly  show  an  increasing
inequality  of  income  distribution.  This  is  a  common  outcome  in  the  early  stages  of

11.
Samoa  is  a  small  island  country  with  a  very  small  economy.  Sustainable
improvements  in  livelihoods  are  constantly  threatened  by  the  country’s  vulnerability  to
external economic shocks and natural disasters. The Commonwealth vulnerability index
ranks  Samoa  in  the  group  of  countries  characterized  by  high  vulnerability.2  Sound
economic diversification may reduce the extent of aggregate export instability, and good
economic  management  can  prevent  general  macroeconomic  instability.  Measures  can
also be taken to improve preparedness for and responses to natural disasters. However,
it must be acknowledged that cyclones like those experienced in 1990 and 1991 can, at
least  temporarily,  derail  the  reform  process  and  undermine  the  growth  needed  to
improve living standards.

12.
The wage-earning sector makes up less than half of those who are classified as
economically active.  Urban village families are more likely to include at least one waged
worker  compared  with  peri-urban  and  rural  villages.  At  the  village  level  the  economic
differences between families are generally not significant. The two main groups who are
likely  to  be  vulnerable  to  poverty  are  urban  villagers  with  limited  land  for  subsistence
production, and rural villagers with limited cash earning opportunities. Other vulnerable
groups include young people, particularly those with less formal education, households
headed by single women, the elderly, and the disabled.

B.

The Education Sector

15.
Samoa  is  a  very  religious  country  and  the  first  school  to  open  in  Samoa  was  a
Catholic Mission school, 150 years ago.  Since then, Christian churches have continued
to play an important role in the provision of education particularly at the secondary level.
Most  of  the  primary  education  and  around  57  percent  of  the  secondary  education  is
under  the  control  of  the  public  education  system  through  village,  district,  and  seven
Government-run  schools.    In  1999,  the  churches  and  private  schools  accounted  for
around 15 percent and 43 percent of the enrollment in primary and secondary education,
respectively.

16.
Over  the  period  1995-1999,  total  school  enrollment  fell  slightly  from  49,093  to
49,018 even though enrollment in Years 1, 2, and 3 continued to increase.  At primary
level  the  great  majority  of  children  attend  Government  schools,4  whereas  at  secondary
level,  private  and  mission  schools  play  a  much  more  substantial  role.  The  quality  of
education  varies  significantly  depending  on  the  type  and  location  of  the  schools  as
shown by the wide difference in pupil/teacher ratios, percentage of untrained teachers,
and Year 8 repetition rates (Appendix 2).

It is Government policy under the terms of the Education Ordinance (1959) that
17.
all children in Samoa must receive primary education.  There is evidence, however, that
some  pupils  drop  out  of  school  in  the  primary  school  years.    The  dropout  rate  at
secondary level is also high. Nevertheless, except for a small number of children living in
the  more  remote  villages,  almost  all  children  in  Samoa  do  begin  primary  school  and
receive some formal education.  The girls enrolled in the early years of primary school
are slightly fewer than the boys, reflecting the gender ratio found in the 1991 census of
the 0-14 years age group.

The Government successfully introduced a number of major educational reforms
18.
in  recent  years  and  significant  progress  has  been  made  in  improving  the  quality,
relevance, and efficiency of education in primary and secondary schools. Furthermore, a
number of projects in various stages of implementation are maintaining the momentum
in  the  reform  process.  There  is  still  a  need  for  improvement  in  the  quality  of  education
and  equity  of  access,  and  in  reducing  the  number  of  dropouts  in  the  primary  and
secondary cycle.

1.

Primary Education

19.
The  primary  education  subsector  comprising  Years  1-8,  with  total  enrollment  in
1999 of 35,790 pupils, consists of (i) 138 village schools,5 attended by 27,060 pupils (76
percent);  (ii)  three  Government-run  schools  on  the  Malifa  campus  attended  by  3,322
pupils (9 percent); (iii) 16 mission schools,6 attended by 4,948 pupils (14 percent); and
(iv) 2 private schools attended by 460 pupils (1 percent). Only the three primary schools
in Malifa are Government owned and come under the direct control of the Department of
Education  (ED).  These  schools  are  very  crowded,  with  large  classes  and  very  high
pupil/teacher ratios. Despite these adverse conditions, a large number of Year 8 pupils

Village primary schools, although classified by ED as Government schools, are in
20.
fact  owned  by  the  community/village  and  managed  through  community-based  school
committees  (SC).    The  SCs  retain  a  large  measure  of  autonomy  in  many  aspects  of

and  its  financial  income  and  expenditure.  ED  provides  the  teachers,  the  teachers’

the schools are visited periodically under its program of school inspection.

Overall, public primary schools differ widely, in their physical layout and facilities
21.
as well as the quality of the education provided.  In some schools, classes do not have
any furniture and the children sit on mats on the floor. In others, the community provides
adequate furniture and equipment and the schools are well maintained.  This variability
also applies to the qualification and experience of teachers, availability of educational aid
material and input, and the status of maintenance of the facilities.

22.
Private  schools  charge  generally  higher  school  fees  than  public  schools,  and
many Samoan families cannot afford to send their children to private schools.  Mission
schools  attract  not  just  members  of  their  congregations,  but  also  many  other  parents
who seek to send their children to such schools for better education.

2.

Secondary Education

23.
Admission  to  secondary  education  is  determined  by  the  national  examination
taken  at  Year  8.    While  the  transition  rate  data  show  some  inconsistencies,  it  shows
clearly that a larger proportion of girls (83.4 percent) than boys (77.6 percent) continue
from Year 8 to Year 9. The breakdown of Year 8-9 transition in all schools for 1999, by
gender and by location, is shown in Appendix 3.

The secondary education subsector, including Years 9-13, with a total enrollment
24.
of  13,228  pupils,  consists  of  (i)  4  Government  senior  colleges,  attended  by  3,020
students  (23  percent);  (ii)  21  public  junior  secondary  schools  (JSS),  attended  by  4,562
students (34 percent); (iii) 16 mission colleges, attended by 4,370 students (33 percent);
(iv) 3 mission JSSs, attended by 1,052 students (8 percent); and (v) 1 private secondary
school, attended by 224 students (2 percent).  Government, private, and mission schools
share  more  evenly  the  responsibility  for  secondary  education,  with  the  latter  having
around  43  percent  of  pupils.  Children  who  score  higher  in  the  Year  8  national
examination  may  gain  access  to  senior  secondary  education  through  one  of  the
Government’s four senior colleges, or in one of the mission colleges or private schools.
A  large  number  of  students  from  the  primary  schools  at  Malifa  gain  access  to
Government  senior  secondary  schools  every  year,  thereby  reducing  access  to  senior
secondary  colleges  to  students  studying  in  the  rural  areas  compared  with  urban
students.

25.
A  large  proportion  of  children  who  achieve  lower  scores  in  the  Year  8  national
examination,  but  still  wish  to  continue  their  formal  education  in  the  public  education
system,  have  to  attend  one  of  the  district  JSSs.  The  district  schools  are  often  ill-
equipped, with inadequate facilities and less qualified teachers to provide high standard

Postsecondary Education

The postsecondary education system does not fall under the responsibility of ED.
26.
The local postsecondary institutions report directly to the Minister of Education, although
ED  exercises  some  policy,  planning,  and  budgetary  liaison  in  respect  of  the  tertiary

tertiary institutions. After completing secondary education, the higher-achieving students
have  the  option  to  continue  to  full-time  higher  education  in  one  of  the  universities  or
institutions either in Samoa or abroad. In 1999, the total enrollment of Samoan students
at  the  postsecondary  level  was  estimated  at  2,900  including  full-time,  part-time,  and

(NUS),  25  attended  the  University  of  South  Pacific  in  Samoa,  and  500  (17  percent)

and a number of smaller specialized centers (225).

27.

students  enrolled  in  the  program.  Other  popular  courses  include  commerce  (303

the  Samoan  education  system,  with  separate  primary  and  secondary  subject

complete the Diploma in Education.

Role of the Department of Education

Despite a generous budget allocation and a sizable amount of grant funds from

information technology is also limited and many administrative processes are still carried

b.

School Management and Administration

36.
Resource management at the school level is not always adequate. This has led
to  (i)  overcrowding  at  the  government-owned  schools  in  Malifa  and  underutilization  of
many  village  and  district  schools;  (ii)  unclear  definition  of  the  composition,  roles,  and
functions  of  village  and  district  SCs;  (iii)  unclear  definition  of  the  role  of  ED;  (iv)
inconsistent or incoherent budgeting procedures; and (v) low morale and a high attrition
rate for principals and teaching staff in public schools.

37. While the Government provides most of the funding for public schools, the local
communities retain ownership of the facilities and considerable independence relating to
the management of the school. While this promotes the building of partnership between
ED  and  the  communities  to  ensure  that  the  schools  meet  their  intended  educational
objectives,  the  quality  of  service  varies  from  school  to  school.    Public  schools  have
access  to  a  number  of  inputs,  but  some  schools  receive  much  less  from  their  local
communities  and  still  lack  some  basic  facilities  such  as  adequate  furniture  or  toilets.
School fees are expected to contribute to preventive maintenance of school facilities, but
they  are  not  always  sufficient  for  that  and  SCs  are  not  always  properly  trained  to
evaluate real maintenance needs.

38.
Although  management  guidelines  for  SCs  have  been  developed,  they  have  not
been widely implemented and are being revised in consultation and with the participation
of  SCs  and  other  stakeholders  as  part  of  the  ISP.  The  main  issues  that  need  to  be
addressed  include  (i)  the  composition  of  the  SCs  and  the  extent  of  active  parental
representation  on  them;  (ii)  the  capacity  of  SCs  members  to  manage  the  affairs  of  the
school  and  the  training  requirements  to  increase  that  capacity;  (iii)  the  level  of
transparency  and  accountability  of  the  SCs  in  the  financial  management  of  the  school;
and  (iv)  the  nature  and  extent  of  the  contractual  agreements  between  SCs  and  ED.  A
further  issue  is  whether  ED  has  the  financial  capacity  to  continue  to  assist  community
schools in the payment of interest on their loans from the Development Bank of Samoa.

c.

Issues Related to Internal Efficiency

39.
There  is  an  urgent  need  to  upgrade  and  rehabilitate  a  large  number  of  school
facilities. There is also evidence that unsuitable or inadequate materials are sometimes
used in schools, primarily because of lack of funds.  A major issue is the recurrent cost
of  maintaining  the  buildings,  fixtures,  fittings,  furniture,  and  equipment.  When  schools
need to be expanded or renovated, one of the main sources of funding in the past has
been  through  community  fund-raising  and  participation,  but  raising  funds  in  the
traditional  way  is  becoming  increasingly  difficult.  SCs  need  to  develop  awareness  and
skills in planning and carrying out regular maintenance programs.

Inadequate equipment and teaching resources, combined with limited in-service
40.
teacher training, represent a notable hindrance to improving educational outcomes at the
school  level.  While  curriculum  materials  and  science  equipment  for  Years  5-8  recently
supplied  under  the  AusAID-financed  Second  Primary  Education  Materials  Project  have
relieved  some  immediate  pressure,  materials  for  the  younger  children  remain  badly
needed and their development is being addressed under the same project. There is also
a  need  for  supplementary  materials,  such  as  readers,  library  books,  charts  and
manufacturing  materials,  and  for  experiential  materials.  Local  suppliers  of  curriculum
materials are few and the schools largely depend on supply from overseas. Both primary
and secondary schools lack adequate libraries. A number of JSSs lack equipment and
resources.  Many schools have a designated science room or laboratory, but equipment
is  often  inadequate  or  simply  lacking.    Facilities  for  other  specialized  curriculum  areas
either do not exist or are not adequately equipped.

41.
Education  for  children  aged  5-14  years  is  compulsory  in  Samoa.  The  national
school  participation  rate  for  this  age  group,  however,  was  only  87.3  percent  in  1992.
Participation showed a moderate increase over the period 1992-1999, and the estimated
figure for 1999 was 93.6 percent, but this figure may not be accurate as it is based on
projections  from  the  1991  census.  Nongovernment  schools  generally  have  significantly
better transition rates than public schools.  It is also of some concern that, apart from the
significant number of children dropping out of school before Year 8, the national rate of
transition from Year 8 to Year 9 (80.3 percent) is still below its 1993 level. Year 8 also
has  a  high  rate  of  repeats  from  students  who  are  unable  to  pass  the  examination  to
secure entry into a secondary school.

42.
As an overall indication of gender difference in transition rates, data from 1995 to
1999 show that retention rates have been rising for both boys and girls but more rapidly
for girls. The retention rates for girls are significantly higher than for boys. In Year 1 boys
slightly  outnumber  the  girls,  but  this  trend  is  clearly  reversed  by  Year  12.  Girls  are
generally better achievers than the boys in the education system. Over the same period,
the  numbers  of  repeaters  in  Years  1-13  fell  significantly  from  2.8  percent  of  total
enrollment to 1.8 percent. In both primary and secondary schools, rates of repetition are
below  1  percent  of  pupils,  but  this  percentage  is  much  higher  in  Year  1  in  primary
schools.

science and practical subjects.

d.

External Efficiency Considerations

45.
Data  from  the  National  Provident  Fund  provide  accurate  information  on  the
formal sector labor market in Samoa, but reliable data regarding employment in the large
informal  economy  are  lacking.  Each  year  about  1,100  new  jobs  are  created  in  formal
employment.  This  number  includes  150  new  positions;  500  jobs  through  retirement,
sickness, or death; and about 450 resulting from emigration. The total number of young
people leaving school at various levels and seeking employment is estimated at 5,200,
significantly higher than available positions, and this is creating a wide employment gap.
Only  about  20  percent  of  those  leaving  school  and  seeking  work  are  employed  in  the
formal sector. It is unlikely that new jobs in formal employment will increase significantly
in  the  near  future.  During  1996-1999,  the  total  number  of  jobs  in  formal  employment
actually declined from 24,548 to 23,120, or a decrease of about 5.8 percent during the
four-year period.

46.
In the context of the development needs of Samoa, the relevance of education at
the  secondary  level  is  particularly  important.  About  75  percent  of  the  total  age  group
does  not  proceed  beyond  Year  11,  and  the  significant  loss  of  development  potential
requires  attention.  Employers  show  a  definite  preference  for  candidates  with  senior
secondary  education  and  are  looking  for  qualifications  of  at  least  Samoa  School
Certificate  (Year  12)  standard.  The  secondary  system  is  widely  considered  to  lack
relevance  to  village  and  labor  market  needs,  with  not  enough  emphasis  on  practical
skills.    Because  of  lack  of  resources  committed  to  applied  subjects  in  JSSs,  students
leaving  the  system  have  limited  ability  in  practical  skills  and  are  unable  or  unwilling  to
respond to employment opportunities in the trade and technical areas.

D.

External Assistance to the Sector

52.
The  Government  is  firmly  committed  to  its  strategy  to  improve  health  and
education  standards.    To  achieve  this  goal,  the  Government  allocates  a  substantial
portion of its recurrent expenditure to these sectors.  Education received an average of
13.7 percent of the total Government expenditure in each of the last four years, second
only to general administration (17.4 percent during the same period). In addition, a high
proportion  of  external  assistance  to  Samoa  is  dedicated  to  education.    The  total  funds
allocated  to  education  and  training  by  each  aid  agency  are  significant:  AusAID  for
instance allocates 42 percent of its annual assistance program to Samoa to education-
related  activities,  including  institutional  strengthening  of  ED  and  scholarship  for  long-
term  training. The  proportion of NZODA’s assistance to education is even higher at 68
percent,  with  a  significant  portion  being  allocated  for  long-term  training  and  for
secondary  education  curriculum  development.    The  EU  microprojects  include  a  58
percent  education  component  comprising  mostly  small  infrastructure  improvements  to
village  schools.  Other  sources,  including  JICA  and  UNDP,  also  allocate  a  significant
portion  of  their  program  to  education.    The  central  issue,  however,  is  the  proportion  of
total resources allocated to each subsector.  A review of external funding shows that the
proportion  to  education  is  heavily  weighted  toward  postsecondary/tertiary  level  (71
percent in 1998/99). During the same period, secondary and primary education received
only  8  percent  and  15  percent  of  total  external  assistance,  respectively,  while  early
childhood education received only 1 percent.

Lessons Learned

A  key  lesson  learned  from  ADB  assistance  in  the  Pacific  is  that  political
56.

ensure  that  it  meets  its  development  objectives.  In  its  third  SES,  the  Government
confirmed its political commitment to the Project. The SES emphasizes the need for an
improved  learning  environment  and  improved  quality  of  education  at  primary  and
secondary levels. This strategic direction constitutes the basic rationale for the proposed

community in subproject preparation and implementation. The commitment of the SCs to
contribute  significantly  to  the  subproject  investment  cost  will  ensure  their  involvement
and ownership.

incorporated in the design of the proposed Project. The synthesis shows that the quality

F.

ADB’s Sector Strategy

58.
Education is an essential element in the process of human, social, and economic
development. The main purpose of investment in education is to empower people with
knowledge,  skills,  and  attitudes  so  as  to  improve  their  quality  of  life,  enhance  their
productivity and their capacity to learn new skills, and enable them to participate fully in
the development process. There is a direct relationship between education and poverty
reduction.  People  with  education  have  higher  income-earning  potential  and  are  better
able to improve the quality of their lives. In this context, ADB’s overarching objective of
poverty  reduction  can  be  better  achieved  through  equity  and  access  to  quality  basic
education.  ADB’s  sector  priorities  with  respect  to  education  are  therefore  to  support
initiatives  that  promote  increased  equity  and  access  and  improved  quality  of  education
services,  strengthen  management  efficiency,  and  mobilize  resources  for  sustainable
education delivery.

59.
In  the  context  of  Samoa,  these  objectives  and  priorities  match  closely  those  of
the Government. In its third SES, the Government stresses its continued commitment to
strengthen  education  and  training,  and  to  ensure  access  to  quality  education  for  all
Samoans.    In  particular  the  SES  recognizes  the  need  to  strengthen  and  improve  the
learning  environment  at  the  primary  level,  and  to  expand  and  improve  the  quality  of
secondary education.  ADB’s sector strategy in Samoa is to support the Government’s
policies  and  strategies  to  improve  the  quality  and  delivery  of  education  services  at
primary and secondary levels.

G.

Policy Dialogue

60.
Policy  dialogue  focused  on  improving  equity  and  the  quality  of  education  while
increasing  relevance  and  efficiency.  More  specifically,  the  discussion  focused  on  (i)

 15

development  of  satellite  primary  and  secondary  schools  to  relieve  pressure  on  Malifa
and  improve  equity  of  access  to  quality  education;  (ii)  extension  of  facilities  in  JSSs  to
offer  a  full  curriculum  to  all  secondary  school  students;  (iii)  development  of  common
building  and  furniture  standards  for  all  schools,  regardless  of  the  source  of  financing;
and  (iv)  improvement  in  the  management  of  the  education  sector  as  a  whole  and  the
primary and secondary schools in particular.

61.
One of the major problems facing ED is the disproportionate number of children
attending school at the three primary and one secondary schools in Malifa. To overcome
this problem, other schools in the greater Apia area and ultimately in the rural areas will
be developed and upgraded to accept the overflow of children from Malifa. A number of
potential  schools  have  been  identified  and  designated  as  satellite  schools  for  this
purpose. In addition to improving the physical facilities of satellite schools, attention will
be  placed  on  improving  the  management  capacity  and  accountability  of  the  SC,
upgrading  teacher  qualifications,  and  providing  better  equipment  and  material  for  an
enhanced learning environment.  The cooperation of other aid agencies in the sector will
be obtained to coordinate these efforts for each school selected.

62.
The maintenance of assets (buildings and equipment) is the responsibility of the
SCs.    The  level  of  maintenance  varies  greatly  from  school  to  school,  depending  on
community involvement  and commitment, management capacity of the  committee, and
affordability.  School  committees  need  awareness  and  skills  training  in  planning  and
carrying  out  a  regular  facilities  maintenance  program.  Through  associated  technical
assistance,  the  SCs  will  be  trained  in  the  preparation  and  implementation  of  a
comprehensive program of preventive maintenance for primary and secondary schools.
The maintenance program will be designed in close cooperation with school authorities,
ED, and Public Works Department (PWD) and, will include safety aspects relating to fire,
cyclones and earthquakes.

63.
The  cost  of  the  education  system  in  Samoa  is  effectively  shared  by  the
Government  and  the  local  community.    The  government  provides  the  teachers,  the
curriculum,  and  related  materials,  while  SCs  raise  funds  to  meet  the  cost  of  facilities,
equipment,  maintenance,  and  consumable  resources.    This  partnership  is  unique  and
needs  to  form  the  basis  of  cost  recovery  strategies.  However,  there  is  need  for  capital
injection from the Government to meet the planned quality improvements. Under similar
externally  assisted  projects,  the  local  communities  are  required  to  bear  a  certain
percentage (10-25 percent) of the costs of infrastructure development, rehabilitation, or
expansion.    Community  contribution  can  typically  be  provided  in  cash  and  in  kind,  and
generally  includes  skilled  and  unskilled  labor  and  materials.    This  mechanism  has
proved to work well with the EU- and JICA-assisted projects, and a similar mechanism
will be applied under the proposed sector loan.

64.
It is estimated that local communities contribute about 13 percent of the recurrent
expenditure  of  primary  and  secondary  education  in  Government  and  mission  schools
through  payment  of  regular  school  fees  alone.    If  additional  funds  raised  by  SCs,
parents,  and  teachers  and  further  contributions  in  kind  are  taken  into  account,
communities  may  already  be  contributing  some  25  percent  of  total  expenditure  on
primary  and  secondary  education.    The  proposed  cost-sharing  arrangement  for  the
project should therefore not raise an affordability issue.

VI.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

102.
The  Project  will  significantly  enhance  internal  efficiency  and  improve  the  quality
of education in the primary and secondary subproject schools. These schools will serve
as models for other public sector schools. Through its design and linkage with other aid-
assisted interventions, the Project will help improve institutional efficiency in the sector. It
will  also  improve  equity  in  access  to  quality  primary  and  secondary  education  and
thereby produce social or equity-related benefits. Lastly, a better qualified workforce will
lead  to  enhanced  general  productivity,  which  is  critical  to  faster  and  more  balanced
economic development in the rural and urban areas of the Samoan economy.

A.

Socioeconomic Analysis

1.

Governance Dimensions

The  Education  Strategic  Plan  is  a  cornerstone  in  the  broader  economic  reform
103.
program  as  described  in  the  latest  SES.  The  Government  has  reiterated  its  strong
commitment to economic reform in general and reemphasized the strategic importance
of improving education and health standards as a critical factor for a better quality of life
for  all  Samoans.  Against  this  backdrop  and  given  the  overall  favorable  governance
environment, the ADB sector Project provides a window of opportunity to further promote
improved governance in public education through devolution of education services and
more effective and efficient overall and financial management in the community schools.

104. One key strategy to improve governance in a decentralized system is to devolve
responsibility  for  provision  of  public  services  to  the  lowest  appropriate  level  of
government. The Project will be instrumental in the effort to decentralize the delivery of
public  education  services  in  the  schools  in  Malifa  to  the  local  community.    School
management of the new Apia elementary school will become the responsibility of a SC
from the local communities. This devolution will enhance equity, and promote community
participation and accountability.

105.
The  public  schools  outside  Malifa  that  will  be  upgraded  under  the  Project  are
managed  by  local  communities.  The  resource  agreement  between  the  school  and  ED
will  provide  an  effective  mechanism  to  reduce  or  eliminate  inconsistencies  in  the
management  of  school  resources.  The  capabilities  of  the  SCs  in  educational  and
financial management will be strengthened under the Project in close coordination with
the AusAID-financed ISP. This intervention will greatly enhance the level of transparency
and accountability at the SC level.

106.
The  Project  will  also  provide  an  opportunity  to  strengthen  the  partnership
between  ED  and  the  subproject  SCs  in  the  management  of  public  primary  and
secondary  schools.  Through  the  local  SCs,  the  communities  retain  considerable
independence  relating  to  school  management.  The  dialogue  and  closer  cooperation
between ED and the SCs will promote decision making by the community, in a manner
fully consistent with specified ED policies. As a result of increased awareness, SCs will
be  better  equipped  to  address  the  issues  of  dropouts  and  exclusion  due  the  parents’
inability to pay school fees.

2.

Economic Justification

107. A key factor in the economic justification of the Project is the social demand for
basic  education.  While  education  is  compulsory  for  the  aged  5-14  years  group,
enrollment of that age group was only 94.3 percent of the school-age population in 1994.
More recently, Non Government Organizations reported that about 2 percent of school-
age children, including those with special needs, never attend school. The dropout rate
is  estimated  to  be  of  a  similar  magnitude.  The  Project  has  a  built-in  mechanism  to
promote schooling for all school-age children, especially in the rural project schools, thus
ensuring that the social demand for basic education will be fully met.

108. While  no  attempt  has  been  made  to  date  to  estimate  the  private  and  social
returns  to  investment  in  primary  and  secondary  education,  there  is  pervasive  evidence
from  pertinent  research  that  formal  basic  education  is  socially  and  economically  more
profitable than any other form of education. Rates of return to investment in education at
various  educational  levels  are  generally  higher  than  the  economic  opportunity  cost  of
capital. Through its focus on primary and secondary education, the Project is expected
to  lay  a  stronger  foundation  for  students  at  the  basic  level,  which  can  result  in  higher
transition  rates  to  postsecondary  education.  This  better  educated  and  more  qualified
group will eventually enjoy higher private returns from employment in the formal public
and private sector in Samoa. A large proportion of postsecondary graduates emigrate to
work  abroad,  resulting  in  considerable  amount  of  remittances  flowing  back  to  the
Samoan economy. This alone is a significant macroeconomic justification for the Project.

109. Given the Project’s main focus on infrastructure improvement, there was limited
scope  for  applying  cost-effectiveness  analysis.  Instead,  least-cost  choices  were
ascertained  and  measures  to  increase  cost-efficiency  were  incorporated  in  the  project
design. The least-cost alternative is based on minimum acceptable standards developed
by  ED.  The  application  of  these  standards  results  in  educationally  functional  buildings,
and the simple construction will result in minimum maintenance costs. An important cost-
saving measure is the proposed design and construction supervision work by PWD staff,
which  has  adequate  expertise  to  perform  this  task  at  the  least  cost.  The  25  percent
community contribution (mainly through the supply of labor) to the civil works component
is another major cost-effective measure.

110.
The Project aims at reducing overcrowding in the Malifa schools and enhancing
greater  access  to  quality  primary  and  secondary  schools  in  the  greater  Apia  area,  the
rural areas in Upolu, and on the island of Savaii. By reducing travel distances and travel
time  for  a  large  number  of  project  beneficiaries,  significant  economic  benefits  (savings
on transport costs and time savings) will be realized.

subjects.  Vocational  subjects  will  be  part  of  the  newly  introduced  curriculum.  On  the
whole,  this  will  increase  secondary  educational  opportunities  in  the  districts  to  a  level
equal to or higher than those in the Apia area.

120.
The  project  framework  includes  three  specific  equity-related  outputs  with  a
corresponding  set  of  performance  indicators  and  monitoring  mechanisms.  The  outputs
are  (i)  improved  access  of  children  from  less  well-off  families  to  quality  primary  and
secondary  education,  (ii)  improved  access  of  children  with  special  needs  to  quality
primary  and  secondary  education,  and  (iii)  more  balanced  distribution  of  educational
facilities  in  rural  areas  (Upolu)  and  on  the  island  of  Savaii.  Appendix  13  presents  a
summary  assessment  of  the  poverty  content  of  the  Project  based  on  a  list  of  12
benchmark  criteria.  The  assessment  shows  that  the  Project  scores  well  on  almost  all
criteria.     

C.

Risks

121.
There is a risk that SCs of the prioritized subproject schools may not be willing to
participate and sign a resource agreement committing the community to participation in
school  improvement.  Safeguard  measures  to  minimize  this  risk  are  as  follows:  (i)
participation  in  the  Project  is  not  compulsory,  and  only  schools  that  show  a  strong
willingness  and  commitment  to  participate  will  be  selected  for  more  in-depth  appraisal;
(ii)  in  recent  years  many  schools  have  contributed  to  aid-sponsored  school  building
programs; (iii) the community will be allowed to contribute in kind (mainly labor) and this
contribution will amount to about 25 percent of the improvement cost; and (iv) the Project
will provide support to implement the management and maintenance program.

The  Government  is  firmly  committed  to  implement  the  restructuring  plan  for  the
122.
Malifa  schools  and  to  carry  out  decentralization  as  soon  as  possible.  Because  of  the
historic importance of Malifa and the public perception that Malifa schools offer the best
quality  public  education  in  Samoa,  there  is  a  risk  that  the  community  will  oppose  the
restructuring  plan. This risk is being minimized as follows. The local community will be
given  the  responsibility  to  manage  the  schools.  A  public  awareness  campaign  is  being
developed  to  familiarize  the  people  with  the  concept  and  purpose  of  the  proposed
satellite schools to provide quality education to a larger number of students.

123.
There  is  also  a  risk  that  ED  may  lack  experience  in  the  implementation  of  an
ADB-funded  sector  loan.  This  risk  will  be  minimized  by  setting  up  a  strong  PMT,

 30

providing substantial project implementation support.  Also, ADB assistance to prepare a
core  subproject  during  loan  processing  will  provide  a  good  example  for  PMT  to  follow.
Furthermore,  TD  has  extensive  experience  with  ADB-funded  projects  and  can  provide
ED with the required assistance in day-to-day administration of the project.

124.
In view of limited resources in PWD, there is a risk that PWD may not be able to
provide  its  intended  services  in  a  timely  manner.  The  selection  of  PWD  is  a  least-cost
solution  and  justified  as  the  availability  of  a  reliable  and  competent  private  sector
providers is limited. PWD has shown a strong commitment to TD to provide the required
architectural services in a timely manner. Moreover, the subproject works are relatively
small and building construction works are simple and standardized. Finally, should PWD
not  be  able  to  deliver  services  in  a  timely  manner,  TD  has  indicated  that  it  would
outsource  these  services  from  the  private  sector,  even  at  a  higher  cost,  so  as  to  keep
the Project on track.

125. Availability of land is not an issue as school expansion, if required, will be on land
belonging  to  the  community.  Timely  provision  of  Government  counterpart  funding  and
community contribution are also not considered a risk as full community involvement is
expected and as the needed Government counterpart funds will be budgeted annually.
The  IRC  after  project  implementation  will  be  very  small  and  will  be  easily  absorbed  by
ED’s  recurrent  budget.  Internal  efficiency  risks  are  also  considered  low.  The  Project  is
likely  to  require  only  a  small  number  of  additional  teachers.  NUS  has  the  capacity  to
supply  more  teachers.  Moreover,  FoE  will  start  a  4-year  Bachelor  of  Education  (BEd)
program  by  2001  and  teachers  with  BEd  degree  will  be  better  qualified  and  have  a
stronger financial incentive to start and continue work as teachers.  Since teachers with
BEd  will  be  paid  a  much  higher  salary  than  teachers  holding  only  a  diploma,  it  is
expected that intake at FoE will increase and the higher expected output of teachers will
ease  the  existing  shortage  of  qualified  teachers  in  the  public  primary  and  secondary
schools.
